content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" is cited as the short title. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. It prohibits failing to comply with royalty payment requirements, making false reports, and imposes penalties for violations. The Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 includes penalties for violations related to royalty payments under mineral leasing laws. Violations can result in triple the unpaid royalty amount plus interest, a $25,000 civil penalty per violation per day, but can be avoided by reporting and correcting the violation within 30 days. Additionally, failing to notify the Secretary of any designations under the Act is considered a lease administration violation. Lease administration violations include failure to notify the Secretary of designations or assignments, refusal to permit entry, inspection, or audit, non-compliance with production notification, and incorrect reporting of operations or financial records. Failure to comply with lease administration requirements, such as reporting production notifications or providing necessary records, may result in penalties of up to $10,000 per violation. Theft of oil or gas without legal authority or dealing with stolen resources can lead to penalties of up to $25,000 per violation. Repeated violations of these regulations may result in further consequences determined by the Secretary or their designee. Failure to comply with lease administration requirements, such as reporting production notifications or providing necessary records, may result in penalties of up to $10,000 per violation. Theft of oil or gas without legal authority can lead to penalties of up to $25,000 per violation. Repeated violations may result in further consequences, including shutting down production on the lease. Repeated violations of lease administration requirements may lead to severe penalties and consequences. The Secretary has the authority to shut down production, prohibit acquiring new leases, cancel or transfer existing leases, and collect reimbursement for costs incurred. Administrative appeals can be made for any determinations of royalties or penalties owed. The Secretary has the authority to impose penalties for lease violations, including canceling or transferring lease sites. Administrative appeals can be made for royalty or penalty determinations. Penalties can be deducted from sums owed by the United States, and the Secretary may compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties shall be served personally by an authorized representative of the Secretary. The Secretary has the authority to impose penalties for lease violations, including canceling or transferring lease sites. Penalties can be deducted from sums owed by the United States, and the Secretary may compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties shall be served personally by an authorized representative of the Secretary, and there is a provision for judicial review of final orders. Any person prescribed for a hearing and aggrieved by a final order of the Secretary under this section may seek review in the United States district court within 90 days. Failure to pay a civil penalty allows the court to award the amount assessed plus interest. No person shall be exempt from the Mineral Leasing Act. The court has jurisdiction to award the assessed amount plus interest after a final judgment in favor of the Secretary. No civil penalty for failure to pay rent for a lease terminated under the Mineral Leasing Act. Violations toll statutes of limitations until corrected or a final order is issued. The person must correct violations and certify all similar violations are fixed for oil and gas leases, or wait for a final order. Records must be maintained until released by the Secretary or expiration of the required period. Amounts from penalties for underpaid royalties are treated as royalties paid under the mineral leasing laws. Amounts received by the United States in an action brought under section 3730 of title 31, United States Code, arising from underpayment of royalties owed under any lease, are treated as royalties paid under the mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965. SEC. 3. SHARED CIVIL PENALTIES. Amendment to the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 to include trebled royalties or 50% of any civil penalty.
